Wirecard introduced its Vision 2025 at its CMD in London on 9-Oct-2018. With large deals traditionally not being part of Wirecard’s mid-term visions (the deal with Crédit Agricole announced on 4-Apr-2018 resulted for example in an increase of Vision 2020 in April 2018) we believe the recently announced partnership with Softbank also implies upside to Wirecard’s Vision 2025.

nightingale20201 Morning all

According to its AGM invitation, Wirecard sees a profit potential from the Softbank partnership (Softbank’s global portfolio companies, market access in Japan and South Korea as well as the development of joint new products and services) in the next five years in the range of EUR 209-273mn (taking into account a discount for the ramp-up phase and excluding the terminal value). However, we don’t know how the deal ramps over the years.

BE11:24am

We don’t know how the deal ramps over the years either. Though, from a purely architectural perspective, ramps can go both up and down.

cheeckychappy @BE - What time do you call this?
BE11:25am

We are taking the mid-point of the expected additional net income from the Softbank partnership in the next five years as base case. If we conservatively assume a net income margin of 20% (our estimate for Wirecard for 2019 which is ~3pp below our estimate for 2021) for the additional revenues, this implies additional revenues of EUR 1.2bn in 2020-2024. If we furthermore assume a take rate of 1.4% (in line with Wirecard’s take rate expected for 2025), the implied additional cumulative transaction volume is EUR 86bn in 2020-2024. To derive the impact for 2025, we conservatively applied Wirecard’s expected CAGR for revenues and transaction volume from Vision 2020-2025, which is 27%. Based on this scenario, the upside of the Softbank deal to Vision 2025 is 8% in terms of transaction volume and revenues.

Sure, why not.

But here's the view for the drinks makers.

BE11:36am

Within the beverages universe, Constellation (covered by Lauren Lieberman) is likely to be affected as it imports a significant amount of beer from Mexico into the US, as will Cuervo (covered by Ben Theurer) as it imports tequila into the US. Amongst the European drinks companies, it is the tequila producers who will be hit hardest, as well as Heineken who sells Mexican beer into the US. Three out of four of our spirits companies under coverage have exposure to tequila in the US (only Remy Cointreau does not).

Diageo PLC (DGE:LSE): Last: 3,320, down 35.83 (-1.07%), High: 3,351, Low: 3,315, Volume: 854.80k
11:38 am
BE11:38am

A 5% tariff will be on the import price, not the shelf price. The shelf price is c.2x higher. Price elasticity in beverages is often 1:1. Therefore a 5% tariff, will likely reduce volumes by c.2.5%, as we would expect the companies to pass the tariff onto the consumer entirely. Elasticity is higher in cheaper brands (Espolon, Cabo Wabo and Altos), and less on more expensive brands (Avion, Don Julio and Casamigos).

As a result of the above, the most affected will be Campari – most reliant on tequila in the US and with cheaper brands, and the least affected will be Pernod, least reliant on tequila in the US and Avion (its larger brand – 2.1% of the 3.6% of US sales) is a more expensive brand.

Clearly Heineken will likely be affected too. Although there is more a beer company can do to offset the tariffs, as the liquid is a lower proportion of the overall cost and longer term, bottling can be done in the US.

However, to put this in context, even for Campari the effect will likely be very small. A 5% tariff is likely to affect US tequila volumes by c.2.5%, meaning group sales could decrease by c.0.1%. A 25% tariff (the highest Trump has threatened), would increase this to 0.5% sales.

We struggle to find in the entire CEEMEA space (and extended EM space) a stock like NMC that offers such strong earnings growth (on which we have relatively good visibility), this level of profitability, and short / medium term catalysts trading at a 2019E and 2020E P/E of c.20x and c.15x, respectively – PEG ratio stands at 0.5x and 0.6x, respectively. Market concerns over the past 10 months have proven to be overblown as the company continues to deliver largely in line with consensus estimates and management guidance.

11:53 am
BE11:53am

FY 2020 appears conservative: The €335m midpoint of the net income guidance of €320m-350m is 7% below consensus of €359m. The company expects total unit costs (per ASK) up 2%, primarily on 7% higher unit fuel costs. However, its fare outlook appears robust versus peers, expecting up low-single-digits in FY 2020. Q1 unit revenue is tracking +4% yoy, we estimate, with fares down and ancillaries sharply up. As in prior quarters, management’s tone on revenue in the meeting (9:00) may offset some of the disappointment to consensus.

BE11:53am

On our forecasts, Wizz trades on 12.7x 2020E P/E. We value Wizz Air on a DCF, which assumes terminal growth of 6% and an EBIT margin of 6.5%, against a WACC of 7.6%. We sense-check our valuation on year-forward EV/EBITDAR and EV/IC multiples. Our target implies a forward EV/IC of 1.3x.

11:55 am
BE11:55am

Though the results are inline and the FY20e net income
guidance is only slightly below the current consensus, the positive outlook, particularly on unit revenues, is better compared to other EU peers. FY20e RASK seen up low single digits implies a similar growth as FY19 (2-3%) with a push from ancillary revenues. 1Q20 is off to a decent start with RASK up +4%. 1H RASK should be even up +5% boosted by ancillary revenue growth of 15% and 3-4% from ticket prices. We would have liked a better figure, but it is still quite decent given the tough yield environment reported by EU peers.

BE11:55am

While we see no significant negative reaction, the upside should be limited given the strong outperformance already at Wizz, shares +37% from the trough in Oct and c.15% YTD.

BE11:56am

And re the conference call, wall of text from Morgan Stanley.

11:56 am
BE11:56am

FY19 market commentary - Vienna - the company remains the lowest cost producer there and the operations break even in first year of operation. Wizz UK - it has been profitable from year one and it operates with 9 aircraft with 2 more to be added shortly. Wizz Air is becoming the largest carrier at London Luton airport. The company does not depend on outbound UK traffic as it has majority inbound UK traffic.Outlook - FY20 is a challenging year but the company is well on track to achieve the net income guidance of €320-350m. Revenue outlook - FY20 ancillary growth trajectory can be seen as +15% per pax in 1H20, +5% per pax in 2H20 and on an annual basis +10% per pax. Summer capacity in Wizz Air markets is growing by around 7% which is much lower versus 13% in the prior year. GDP growth in key markets of the company continues to remain strong (1Q19 Hungary GDP growth by +5.3% and Poland by +4.9%). Costs outlook: Flat unit costs for FY20 reflects the cost savings coming from the A321’s and normalisation of labour costs but headwinds are from maintenance costs. The company does not expect similar growth in labour costs in FY20 like FY19 (was up +9%). The cost savings from its new aircrafts continue to be in line with company expectations. By the end of FY20 the airline will have 50% of its seats on the A321’s. The company notes there are challenges with the delivery of the Airbus aircrafts as well. On M&A and Capacity consolidation the messaging continues to be the same - the company is not interested in acquiring businesses but is interested in capturing expanding opportunities in the market. Q&A: Philosophically the company thinks it can lower fares and generate higher ancillary revenues. As a result they think they will give back around 5% on fares but gain 15% on the ancillary revenue in 1H20. The company thinks ancillary revenue is more resilient, so remains comfortable with this strategy. Summer bookings - it is 4% ahead YoY in 1Q20 and is 2% ahead YoY in 2Q20. Unionisation of labour - the management is making relentless efforts to engage and so far employees remain satisfied. Brexit update - with regards to access to market the airline has Wizz Air UK and Wizz Air Europe. On ownership and control the company has contingency plan of disenfranchisement and has been pre-approved by Euro commission.

BE12:08pm

representing 61% of Stride shares. The Offer is expected to become effective during the third quarter of 2019.
• Rank highlights the following consequences of the acquisition:
• Create a business with genuine scale and capability in the digital market. Rank will have pro forma digital net gaming revenues of approximately £185m, supported by a strong proprietary technology platform. It will be the #2 player in UK online bingo with an 18% market share and the #6 player in UK online gaming with a 4% market share.
• Create a leading multi-channel operator in the UK. Stride is an established scale player operating in a highly regulated market with a portfolio of leading online bingo and casino brands that are highly complementary to Rank’s leading multi-channel bingo and casino offerings.
• Improve Rank’s performance and reduce costs through migration to Stride’s proprietary technology platform and in-house ecosystem. By migrating Rank’s existing online business onto Stride’s proprietary technology platform and operating ecosystem, Rank expects to benefit from increased control and performance, as well as significant identified cost savings.

BE12:08pm

• Strengthen Rank’s management team. As part of the acquisition, Stride’s senior leadership team including Eitan Boyd and Darren Sims, currently Chief Executive Officer and Chief Operating Officer of Stride respectively, have agreed to lead the digital operations of the combined business and be responsible for implementing the technology migration.
• Create significant value from strong synergies. Based on a detailed analysis Rank believes that the combination will result in at least £13m of pre-tax recurring annual cost savings by the third year following completion.
• Synergies. Rank also believes that the combination should generate revenue synergies through cross-selling, implementation of agile systems and marketing techniques, acceleration of its international expansion through Stride’s scalable and agile platform and the use of Stride’s brands and proprietary content to maximise the lifetime value of customers. The acquisition of Stride is expected to be accretive to Rank’s earnings per share in the first year following completion.
• Continued financial flexibility. Rank expects the Enlarged Entity to have pro forma net debt to pro forma adjusted EBITDA of 1.0x. Rank expects the Enlarged Entity to have sufficient financing resources to sustain Rank’s existing dividend and to pursue selective M&A supported by a rapid deleveraging profile.

12:15 pm
BE12:15pm

The steady devaluation of Earls Court tells us very little about the London housing market, of course. It was a wrongheaded project in the wrong part of town and under the wrong council administration ....

BE12:16pm

Kempen are good here, being property specialists.

BE12:17pm

In the midst of refuting the legality of Compulsory Purchase Orders (CPO)
by local councils on Earls Court, this morning Capco has announced that
Transport for London (TFL), its JV partner on the site, has obtained an
independent valuation from JLL for its year end financial statements. Based
on this 03/19A valuation, the value of Capco’s interests in Earls Court has
fallen to £412m, representing a l-f-l decrease of -10.5% versus 12/18A (£461m). To put this in context this value decline is roughly in line with the valuation writedown we had for the 19FY, and on a standalone basis (ie. excluding Covent Garden which represents c.80% of the portfolio) the pro forma 12/18A NAV is reduced by a further 1.8% (c.6p) to 320p, (Kempen 19H1 est. 321p). The reason for the valuation decline is due to a number of adjustments to component parts of the valuation, including an increased developers margin (now greater than 24%?), as well as further reductions in the outlook for gross development value.
Capco remains in a tricky situation in our view as it cannot kick start ECPL plans without the backing of third party capital, which is unlikely to step in until we get more clarity over Brexit. At the same time the local borough council continues to publicly denounce the scheme for the lack of activity there while London is in need of more homes, and threatens a CPO (which it currently doesn’t have the legal framework to execute). Although we believe Capco is ultimately doing the right thing by halting de-merger plans, those who feel there are no more writedowns on Earls Court to come have once again been proven wrong, and Capco continues to take the pain. Maintain Sell.

UltraShort Somalia ETF It's time to short Somalia, guys
12:18 pm
BE12:18pm

And Numis.

red s&p 2720 key retracement level. tin hats if closes below.
BE12:19pm

[O]ur forecasts
assume a 15% w/down through FY19E. We estimate this takes the total w/down to
c.53% from the peak of £51.8m/acre at Jun-15; the cause of the latest w/down is “a
number of adjustments have been made to the component parts of the valuation,
including increased developer’s margin and total development cost assumptions
as well as a more conservative view on gross development value.” In other words, the valuation continues to come under pressure from all angles and we do not believe that this will mark the end of the w/down cycle. While the current equity rating implies effectively nil value for Earls Court, we believe this is justified given the political ill-will that exists with LBHF which is proving a major impediment to delivery and we note recent press speculation that LBHF may announce, in Sept-19, an attempt at a CPO of the whole of the broader Earls Court site (including the CLSA land and TfL depot) at a value materially below the current book value. Factoring in the revised valuation, NAV reduces 6p to 320p proforma; the shares trade on -33% vs proforma NAV and we remain cautious on the outlook, with a low likelihood in our view of a third party bid for either the whole of ECPL or smaller sub-packages of land over the near/medium term.

12:22 pm
BE12:22pm

NEW YORK, NY (May 31, 2019) – Time Out Market New York opens its doors to the public today. The highly anticipated food and cultural market brings the best of the city under one roof with 21 eateries with food from some of New York’s top chefs and restaurateurs, cocktails from renowned mixologists and cultural experiences by local talent – all handpicked by Time Out New York’s editorial team.

Occupying 21,000 square feet across two floors of the historic Empire Stores at 55 Water Street, Time Out Market New York brings a new and unique experience to Dumbo, Brooklyn. The ground floor hosts 17 culinary concepts along with two full bars and communal-style seating. The fifth-floor has four additional chef-driven eateries, a full bar and an outdoor rooftop overlooking the East River, providing guests with spectacular views of the Brooklyn Bridge and Manhattan’s skyline; the top floor is also where the stage is located for cultural experiences and performances from local artists, DJs and bands. The architecture of the market blends with the building’s original industrial feel with modern design elements, making the space not only a culinary but also a visual feat.
